The Posse Foundation
Founded 1989; 29 years ago (1989)
Founder Deborah Bial
Type Education
Location
  • 14 Wall Street,
    New York, New York 10005, U.S.
Area served
United States
Method Identifies, recruits and trains student leaders to pursue their academics and to help promote cross-cultural communication on campus.
Key people
 Jeffrey Ubben, Former Board Chairman
Deborah Bial, President & Founder
Revenue (2016)
$21,864,016[1]
Expenses (2016) $22,479,487[1]
Website www.possefoundation.org
2016 Posse Foundation Annual Report

The Posse Foundation is an American nonprofit organization that identifies, recruits, and trains student leaders from public high schools to form multicultural teams called "Posses" of 10 Posse Scholars. These teams are then prepared, through an intensive eight-month Pre-Collegiate Training Program, for enrollment at top-tier universities nationwide to pursue their academics, help promote cross-cultural communication and become leaders on college campuses. Each Posse Scholar is awarded a full-tuition scholarship.[2]

Goals[edit]

Posse has three goals designed to address some critical issues of importance to institutions of higher education in the United States today:

  1. To expand the pool from which top colleges and universities can recruit outstanding young leaders from diverse backgrounds.
  2. To help these institutions build more interactive campus environments so that they can become more welcoming institutions for people from all backgrounds.
  3. To ensure that Posse Scholars persist in their academic studies and graduate so they can take on leadership positions in the workforce.

(From the Posse Foundation Web site.)

Posse Scholars Pre-Collegiate Training Program[edit]

For eight months before they begin their college career, Posse Scholars attend a weekly Pre-Collegiate Training Program. The goal of this training program is to prepare Posse Scholars for as many as possible of the academic, social, and personal challenges they may face in their college career.

Program overview and history[edit]

While the program began as a partnership with a single school (Vanderbilt University[3]), Posse has grown to partner with 56 colleges and universities;[4][5] as of 2018 Posse has matched over 8,400 students with full-tuition college scholarships.[6]

In 2007, it was among over 530 New York City arts and social service institutions to receive part of a $20 million grant from the Carnegie Corporation, which was made possible through a donation by New York City Mayor Michael Bloomberg.[7]

The Posse Foundation's founder, Deborah Bial, received the prestigious MacArthur Fellowship in 2007, honoring her work with Posse to address the challenges of college access for underrepresented populations.[8][9]

In March 2010, President Barack Obama donated a portion of his $1.4 million Nobel Peace Prize award money to The Posse Foundation. The Posse Foundation was one of ten organizations to receive this honor.[10][11]

Posse Veterans Program[edit]

In 2013, The Posse Foundation implemented a program with a new recruitment strategy to choose veterans who they feel have a potential for academic excellence at selective four-year institutions of higher education.[12] By applying the core Posse principle to group 10 Scholars per university, they prepare veterans for the college experience and support them through to graduation.[13]

The Posse Veterans Program [14] began in partnership with Vassar College[15] and now also counts Wesleyan University,[16] Dartmouth College,[17] the University of Virginia[18] and the University of Chicago[19] as partners. Former Vassar President Catharine Bond Hill said of the original idea, "I think it adds to the education on campus to have students with different experiences."[20] Vassar, Wesleyan, UVA, UChicago and Dartmouth supplement available G.I. Bill and Yellow Ribbon funding to guarantee full tuition support for every veteran student selected.

Posse STEM Program[edit]

Posse began recruiting STEM-specific Posses in collaboration with Brandeis University in 2008.[21] The program notably expanded to 10 partner schools in 2014,[22] announced at a White House summit[23] on higher education.[24][25]

PossePlus Retreat[edit]

The PossePlus Retreat (PPR) is a collaborative, focused group discussion on a contemporary issue which Posse Scholars and invited college community members conduct each year in a retreat setting.[26]

In 2008, "Social Responsibility" was chosen as the first PossePlus Retreat theme. Following years' PPR themes have been "Education" (2009), "Do we still need to talk about race?" (2010), "The Millenials" (2011),[27] "Born This Way? Gender and Sexuality in the 21st Century" (2012),[28] "What's Your Worth? Class, Power and Privilege in America" (2013),[29] "Revolt? Rethink? Reform?" (2014),[30] "Crime and Punishment" (2015),[31][32] "Sticks and Stones: Language and Speech in a Diverse Society" (2016),[33][34] "Us Vs. Them" (2017)[35][36] and "Hope, Hate and Race in the United States" (2018).[37][38][39]

Notable Posse alumni[edit]

  • Rana Abdelhamid, Founder of WISE, Amnesty International USA Board Member[40] - Middlebury College Posse alumna[41][42]
  • Koby Altman, General Manager of the Cleveland Cavaliers - Middlebury College Posse alumnus[43][44]
  • Shirley Collado, President of Ithaca College - Vanderbilt University Posse alumna[45]
  • Mouhamadou Diagne, Muslim Chaplain at Bucknell University - Carleton College Posse alumnus[46][47]
  • Gabrielle Farrell, Press Secretary for Elizabeth Warren 2018 reelection campaign - Bryn Mawr College Posse alumna[48]
  • Adrian Lievano, Co-Founder and CEO of Everwaters - University of Pennsylvania Posse alumnus[49][50]

Assets[edit]

As of 2016 the Posse Foundation had assets of $83,256,943.[1]

Funding details[edit]

Funding details as of 2016:[1]

Revenue and support as of 2016: $21,864,016

  Contributions and grants (50.3%)
  University fees (11.6%)
  Service fees (3.5%)
  In-kind contributions (4.0%)
  Investment income (13.1%)
  Fundraisingevents, net of direct benefits to donors (17.5%)

Expenses as of 2016: $22,479,487

  Recruitment and training programs (76.1%)
  Management and general (12.4%)
  Fundraising (11.5%)
